Detection of Methane Using Hyperspectral Imagery

Existing methods for detecting methane using hyperspectral imagery are effective but often come with high computational demands and associated costs, limiting their practical applications. To address these limitations, we propose the Mamba MethaneMapper (MMM), a cost-effective and efficient AI-driven solution designed to enhance methane detection capabilities in hyperspectral images. MMM incorporates two key innovations that collectively improve performance while managing costs.

First, we utilize a GPU-aware state-space encoder, which optimizes the computational resources and efficiency of the system. Second, MMM uses an environment-sensitive module to prioritize image regions likely containing methane emissions, which are then analyzed by our efficient Mamba algorithm. This selective approach improves the accuracy of methane detection and significantly reduces unnecessary computations and memory consumption.

Introduction

We address the challenge of detecting and pinpointing methane (CH4) plumes using multispectral and hyperspectral imaging data as an object detection and segmentation problem. Identifying and locating potential methane emission hotspots is a crucial initial step in mitigating global warming caused by greenhouse gases. Methane is responsible for approximately 20% of the global warming effect attributed to greenhouse gases. Its Global Warming Potential (GWP) is 86 times greater than that of carbon dioxide (CO2) over a 20-year timeframe. This underscores the urgent need to monitor and reduce methane emissions.

Methane persists in the atmosphere for an average of 7.9 years, and its atmospheric concentration has been rising steadily since the industrial revolution. While the annual increase in methane levels slowed between 1999 and 2006, it began to rise again in 2007. Methane emissions have many sources, but those from the oil and natural gas industries are of particular interest. According to the United States Environmental Protection Agency report, methane emissions from these industries account for 84 million tons per year.

Current efforts to detect these sources mostly depend on aerial imagery. The Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) has conducted thousands of aerial surveys in the last decade to collect data using an airborne sensor. Several methods have been proposed to detect potential emission sites from such imagery. Most existing methods exhibit high sensitivity to background context and variations in land-cover types, leading to a substantial number of false positives. These false detections typically require considerable intervention from domain experts.

To address these limitations, we propose the Mamba MethaneMapper (MMM) architecture, which is shown in Figure 1. The hyperspectral image input is processed through a feature selector block, which isolates the salient bands within the RGB (400-700nm) and SWIR (2000-2500nm) channels. These isolated channels are fed into the backbone feature extractor. The spectral filter identifies potential methane regions, which are used as masks to select specific spatial locations in the extracted features. These features are then encoded by the state-space encoder and decoded by the hyperspectral decoder to predict bounding boxes and segmentation masks for methane detection.

Mamba MethaneMapper Architecture

We address the challenge of detecting and pinpointing methane (CH4) plumes using multispectral and hyperspectral imaging data as an object detection and segmentation problem. To mitigate the limitations of existing methods, we propose a novel framework that replaces the attention mechanism in transformer architectures with a Mamba-S6 state space block. This block reduces the quadratic computational complexity of the attention mechanisms to linear complexity.

However, due to the nature of hyperspectral data, simply replacing the attention mechanism will not render an efficient architecture. Therefore, we propose an environment-dependent selection strategy in the form of a feature selector block. In summary, MMM will incorporate two primary innovative modules. First, it will integrate a GPU-optimized state-space encoder, which is designed to maximize computational efficiency. Second, MMM will employ an environment-adaptive feature selector to select regions that are likely to contain methane emissions.

Data Overview

For initial development and preliminary exploration, we will use the Methane Hot Spots (MHS) dataset. We will train and test on the subset of the dataset from 2015, which includes flightlines from the Four-Corner region.
